description:
Enter a world in the distant future, where Bounty Hunters roam the solar system. Spike and Jet, bounty hunting partners, set out on journeys in an ever struggling effort to win bounty rewards to survive.

While traveling, they meet up with other very interesting people. Could Faye, the beautiful and ridiculously poor gambler, Edward, the computer genius, and Ein, the engineered dog be a good addition to the group?
synonyms: คาวบอย บีบ๊อป

tags.name: Space
tags.description: Partly or completely set in outer space.

tags.name: Crime
tags.description: Centers around unlawful activities punishable by the state or other authority.

tags.name: Episodic
tags.description: Features story arcs that are loosely tied or lack an overarching plot.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Primarily Adult Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters above a high school age.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Noir
tags.description: Stylized as a cynical crime drama with low-key visuals.

tags.name: Travel
tags.description: Centers around character(s) moving between places a significant distance apart.

tags.name: Anti-Hero
tags.description: Features a protagonist who lacks conventional heroic attributes and may be considered a borderline villain.

tags.name: Philosophy
tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.name: Guns
tags.description: Prominently features the use of guns in combat.

tags.name: Cyberpunk
tags.description: Set in a future of advanced technological and scientific achievements that have resulted in social disorder.

tags.name: Male Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is male.

tags.name: Found Family
tags.description: Features a group of characters with no biological relations that are united in a group providing social support.

tags.name: Terrorism
tags.description: Centers around the activities of a terrorist or terrorist organization.

tags.name: Female Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is female.

tags.name: Cowboys
tags.description: Features Western or Western-inspired cowboys.

tags.name: Martial Arts
tags.description: Centers around the use of traditional hand-to-hand combat.

tags.name: Cyborg
tags.description: Prominently features a human character whose physiological functions are aided or enhanced by artificial means.

tags.name: Tomboy
tags.description: Features a girl who exhibits characteristics or behaviors considered in many cultures to be typical of boys.

tags.name: Amnesia
tags.description: Prominently features a character(s) with memory loss.

tags.name: Gambling
tags.description: Centers around the act of gambling.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Yakuza
tags.description: Centered around Japanese organised crime syndicates.

tags.name: Drugs
tags.description: Prominently features the usage of drugs such as opioids, stimulants, hallucinogens etc.

tags.name: Police
tags.description: Centers around the life and activities of law enforcement officers.

tags.name: Tanned Skin
tags.description: Prominently features characters with tanned skin.

tags.name: Cult
tags.description: Features a social group with unorthodox religious, spiritual, or philosophical beliefs and practices.

tags.name: Nudity
tags.description: Features a character wearing no clothing or exposing intimate body parts.

tags.name: Circus
tags.description: Prominently features a circus.

tags.name: CGI
tags.description: Prominently features scenes created with computer-generated imagery.

title.native: カウボーイビバップ天国の扉
シューティングスタービバップ カウボーイビバップ
カウボーイビバップ よせあつめブルース

name.native: スパイク・スピーゲル
フェイ・バレンタイン
アップルデリー・シニズ・ヘサップ・リュトフェン
アンディ・フォン・デ・オニアテ
エドワード・ウォン・ハウ・ペペル・チブルスキー4世

node.description: Mary Elizabeth McGlynn is an American voice actress, ADR director and singer-songwriter best known for her involvement in music production in multiple games from the Silent Hill series, and her extensive English-language dubbing of various anime, animated films and video games.

Kanno's earliest experiences with music came from attending church with her parents. She studied keyboard from a young age on both the piano in her home and the organ at her kindergarten. In elementary school, she began participating in composition contests, but in high school, Kanno began to take more of an interest in literature than in music.

She attended Waseda University, where she majored in literature, but she transcribed music for various student groups at Waseda in her free time. While in university, Koei, a Japanese video game company, asked her to compose the soundtrack to Nobunaga's Ambition. The game turned out to be a hit, and Kanno's music career was launched.

Kanno has also composed music for artists such as [Maaya Sakamoto](https://anilist.co/staff/95090/), [Megumi Nakajima](https://anilist.co/staff/96105/) and [Kyouko Koizumi](https://anilist.co/staff/164646/). She is also a keyboardist, as well as the frontwoman for [Seatbelts](https://anilist.co/staff/193673/), who perform many of Kanno's compositions and soundtracks.

She has collaborated with directors [Shinichirou Watanabe](https://anilist.co/staff/97009/) and [Shouji Kawamori](https://anilist.co/staff/97501/) multiple times.

In addition to Japanese, she speaks a little English and some French.

Most known for directing critically and commercially successful series, [Cowboy Bebop](https://anilist.co/anime/1/) and [Samurai Champloo](https://anilist.co/anime/205/).

He is noted for blending together multiple genres in his anime. For example, in Cowboy Bebop, classic cowboy western mixes with '60s/'70s New York City film noir, jazz/blues music, Hong Kong action movies, and to top it off the series is set in space. In his later work, Samurai Champloo, he unites the cultures of Okinawa, hip hop, modern-day Japan, and chanbara.

**Michiko Yokote** is a Japanese scriptwriter. She is the pupil of [Kazunori Itou](https://anilist.co/staff/97941).

[Website](http://www.yatate.net/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/yatate_hajime) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/矢立肇) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hajime_Yatate)

Hajime Yatate is a collective pseudonym for [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/)'s staff.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/信本敬子)

Nobumoto made her debut as a scriptwriter in 1989 on TV drama, and on anime two years later with [Fly! Peek the Whale](https://anilist.co/anime/2314/).

Widely known for her work on hit titles such as [Cowboy Bebop](https://anilist.co/anime/1/), [Tokyo Godfathers](https://anilist.co/anime/759/) and [Macross Plus](https://anilist.co/anime/474/). She is noted as the original creator of [Wolf’s Rain](https://anilist.co/anime/202/). She also contributed scripts for [Samurai Champloo](https://anilist.co/anime/205/), [Space Dandy](https://anilist.co/anime/20057/) and [Carole & Tuesday](https://anilist.co/anime/101281/).

She passed away on December 1, 2021 after a battle with esophageal cancer.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/信本敬子)

Nobumoto made her debut as a scriptwriter in 1989 on TV drama, and on anime two years later with [Fly! Peek the Whale](https://anilist.co/anime/2314/).

Widely known for her work on hit titles such as [Cowboy Bebop](https://anilist.co/anime/1/), [Tokyo Godfathers](https://anilist.co/anime/759/) and [Macross Plus](https://anilist.co/anime/474/). She is noted as the original creator of [Wolf’s Rain](https://anilist.co/anime/202/). She also contributed scripts for [Samurai Champloo](https://anilist.co/anime/205/), [Space Dandy](https://anilist.co/anime/20057/) and [Carole & Tuesday](https://anilist.co/anime/101281/).

She passed away on December 1, 2021 after a battle with esophageal cancer.

Shouji Kawamori is an anime creator, director and mechanical designer. Also a current advisor for [Satelight](https://anilist.co/studio/41/).

Famous for his work in the [Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1088/) and Transformers franchises. He pioneered several innovative concepts in his works, such as transforming mecha (including the VF-1 Valkyrie in Macross and Optimus Prime in Transformers) and virtual idols (including Lynn Minmay and Sharon Apple in the Macross franchise).

Kawamori attended Keio University together with Macross screenwriter [Hiroshi Oonogi](https://anilist.co/staff/97701/) and character designer [Haruhiko Mikimoto](https://anilist.co/staff/96968/). There they became friends and founded a [Mobile Suit Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/80/) fan club called "Gunsight One," a name the group would use years later during the development of the fictional world of the Macross series. Later on his career Kawamori created or co-created the concepts which served as basis for several anime series. His projects are usually noted to contain strong themes of love, war, spirituality or mysticism, and ecological concern.

Kawamori also helped to design various toys for the Takara toyline, Diaclone in the early '80s. Among them the first Optimus Prime toy design, Prowl, Bluestreak, Smokescreen, Ironhide, and Ratchet. Over 20 years later, he returned to Transformers by designing both the Hybrid Style Convoy and the Masterpiece version of Starscream for Takara.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/岡村天斎) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tensai_Okamura)

During his university days at Waseda University, Okamura was a part of Waseda's manga research society and together with other budding animators, produced his first independent anime there. Upon graduating from university, Okamura joined the animation production studio Madhouse as an animator through the recommendation of a friend. Lensman was the first series he worked on as an animator. The first anime movies that he worked on were Kamui no Ken and Bobby ni Kubittake. 

In 1989, he made his debut as an episode director with Yawara! and soon made his full directorial debut in 1995 with Memories. He later left Madhouse and went freelance, working on several projects along the way.

In 1991, he changed his first name from Yutaka to Tensai.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/satojumichi) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/佐藤順一)

Junichi Satou is a Japanese anime director, best known for working on shoujo-based anime and in the magical girl genre. He was formerly associated with [TYO Animations](https://anilist.co/studio/333/), formerly known as [Hal Film Maker](https://anilist.co/studio/34/).

Satou’s first major work was directing the first, and a portion of the second season of [Sailor Moon](https://anilist.co/anime/530/) for [Toei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/18/), after which he handed the position over to [Kunihiko Ikuhara](https://anilist.co/staff/100082/), although he continued to storyboard and direct episodes for the later seasons. Satou later went on to co-direct [Ojamajo Doremi](https://anilist.co/anime/350/) alongside [Takuya Igarashi](https://anilist.co/staff/105087/), as well as the critically acclaimed [Princess Tutu](https://anilist.co/anime/721/). Satou served as chief director for long-runner [Sgt. Frog](https://anilist.co/anime/516/), and in recent years has become more known for his iyashikei works such as [Aria](https://anilist.co/anime/477/) and [Tamayura](https://anilist.co/anime/9055/).

He's married to [Yasuno Satou](https://anilist.co/staff/144094/).

(Source: Wikipedia)
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/staffwhy)
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/佐藤大)
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/magushigeyasu)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/南雅彦) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masahiko_Minami)

A founder and representative director of studio [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/). Also the leading producer of its Studio B.

After graduating from Osaka University of Arts, Minami joined [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/) in 1984. There he did desk work and served as a production assistant on many of [Masuo Ueda](https://anilist.co/staff/148840/)'s productions. He was promoted to producer on [Musha Knight Commando](https://anilist.co/anime/9087/) in 1991, and from there he went on to produce shows such as [Mobile Fighter G Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/96/), [Vision of Escaflowne](https://anilist.co/anime/182/) and [Cowboy Bebop](https://anilist.co/anime/1/). In 1998, he left Sunrise and established Bones with [Toshihiro Kawamoto](https://anilist.co/staff/103531/) and the late [Hiroshi Ousaka](https://anilist.co/staff/107410/). He was elected as the representative director of the studio and has held the position since.

Minami's classmates at university included [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/), [Hiroyuki Yamaga](https://anilist.co/staff/100988/), and [Kazuhiko Shimamoto](https://anilist.co/staff/97479/). He appears as a character in the manga [Aoi Honoo](https://anilist.co/manga/55292/), which Shimamoto wrote about his own university days. The manga also received a TV drama adaptation, in which Minami was portrayed by actor Kaname Endou.

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Website](https://endoh-masaaki.com/) | [Youtube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCBnCeOigma9Cv6eI5_QleQQ) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/遠藤正明) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masaaki_Endoh)

Masaaki Endou is a Japanese singer-songwriter who is prominent in the area of soundtracks for anime and tokusatsu productions. He is one of the founders of the Anison band JAM Project and has been a regular member ever since its inception in 2000. His nickname is the "Young Lion of Anison" and he goes by the motto "Always Full Voice".

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/sekise10) | [Sakugabooru](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post?tags=yutaka_nakamura) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/中村豊_(アニメーター%29)

Yutaka Nakamura graduated from Yoyogi Animation Gakuin and first joined studio Ad Cosmo. After switching several studios; from Art Office Sharaku, to Anime Torotoro, to [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/), he eventually settled at [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/) with a contract.

Nakamura is considered to be among the best action animators, with his scenes featuring catchy movement and effects. Some of his recognizable traits include camera shaking, blurs, and bending and stretching high-speed objects. His fights are praised for its weighty, intense choreographies that are heavy on impact frames. His signature trait is drawing debris as simple cubes, consequentially named "Yutapon Cubes," which are stylistic and easy to draw. Despite being responsible for popularizing it, Nakamura has stated that he started doing it when he noticed [Satoru Utsunomiya](https://anilist.co/staff/101489/) doing it. 

(Source: Animators Wiki)

Steve Conte (pronounced /ˈkoʊnt/) is a member and the lead singer of the band The Contes along with his brother John Conte. He is also the lead singer of Crown Jewels, and is the current lead guitarist of the New York Dolls. In his youth, Steve was the lead guitarist and backing singer in the band Waddi And The Waddettes. Conte first became known to the music industry through his band Company of Wolves (Mercury Records) in the early 1990s. Steve has done studio and/or live work with artists like Peter Wolf, Willy DeVille, Maceo Parker, Billy Squier, Suzi Quatro, Jill Jones, Paul Simon, Simon & Garfunkel, Phoebe Snow, David Johansen & The Harry Smiths, Chuck Berry, Willie Nile and many others. Conte occasionally plays guitar with Eric Burdon & The Animals.    He has also worked with composer Yoko Kanno and lyricist Tim Jensen in music for several anime series. Steve Conte sang the opening theme, Stray, to the Studio BONES' anime series Wolf's Rain as well as the tracks Heaven's Not Enough and Could You Bite the Hand? on both of the anime's soundtracks. Conte can also be heard in some episodes of Cowboy Bebop, most notably for the song Call Me Call Me, as well as Words That We Couldn't Say, No Reply, and the CD version of Rain, sung by Mai Yamane in the series. More recently, he sang the ending theme to Ghost in the Shell: Stand Alone Complex 2nd GIG; Living Inside the Shell alongside with Shanti Snyder. He also performed on the duet "The Garden of Everything" with Japanese singer Maaya Sakamoto on her RahXephon-related single "Tune the Rainbow".    He most recently provided the vocals for the video game Sonic and the Secret Rings closing credits song titled Worth a Chance, and the game's main theme Seven Rings In Hand. Songs which did not make the final soundtrack of the game include Midget In A Rocket and Lute To A Cow.    Currently, Conte is planning another tour, during 2009, as evidenced by a poster he left on the MySpace website for Deborah Harry (lead singer of the band Blondie).

A co-founder and a board member of [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/).

Upon graduating from high school, Kawamoto was first employed in the making and designing of precision machinery. During this early period, he became interested in becoming an animator due to the ongoing [Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1088/) series, [Yoshiyuki Tomino](https://anilist.co/staff/97337/)'s [Mobile Suit Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/80/) and [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/)'s amateur [Daicon](https://anilist.co/anime/2724/) films. In particular, [Yoshikazu Yasuhiko](https://anilist.co/staff/97220/)'s work was a major influence.

After graduating, he applied for a small sub-contracting studio called Group Donguri and was accepted. In 1986, he made his debut in Yasuhiko's 1986 film [Arion](https://anilist.co/anime/791/). During the production he was mentored by the character designer [Sachiko Kamimura](https://anilist.co/staff/112663/), with whom he would later work with on multiple occasions, including being her assistant in [Venus Wars](https://anilist.co/anime/544/), which was also written and directed by Yasuhiko. After this Kawamoto worked on numerous series by [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/), most notably as a character designer on the Gundam entries, [Stardust Memory](https://anilist.co/anime/84/) and [The 08th MS Team](https://anilist.co/anime/81/), as well as the internationally acclaimed [Cowboy Bebop](https://anilist.co/anime/1/).

In 1998, he co-founded Bones with fellow Sunrise staff members [Masahiko Minami](https://anilist.co/staff/101519/) and [Hiroshi Ousaka](https://anilist.co/staff/107410/). Some of the more recent works he has provided designs for include [Wolf's Rain](https://anilist.co/anime/202/), [Ghost Slayers Ayashi](https://anilist.co/anime/1587/), [Noragami](https://anilist.co/anime/20447/) and [Kekkai Sensen](https://anilist.co/anime/20727/).

**Non-anime staff credits:**
~!
- Character Design - "Gigantic Drive" (Video game)
- Character Design - "Kidou Senshi Gundam A year of War" (Video game)
- Character Design - "Kidou Senshi Gundam Cross Dimension 0079" (Video game)
- Character Design - "Kidou Senshi Gundam F91 Formula Senki 0122" (Video game)
- Character Design - "Kidou Senshi Gundam Return of Zion" (Video game)
- Character Design - "Kidou Senshi Gundam Senki" (Video game)
- Character Design - "OUT LIVE Be Eliminate Yesterday" (Video game)
- Character Design - "OUT LIVE" (Video game)
- Character Design - "Wonder Project J" (Video game)
- Character Design - "Robot Alchemic Drive" (Video game)
- Assistant Chief Animation Director - "OVER THE MONOCHROME RAINBOW" (Video game)
- Animation Director - "Ghost in the Shell" (Video game)
- Animation Director - "Kidou Senshi Gundam" (Video game)
- Key Animation for "Ghost in the Shell" (Video game)
- Key Animation - "Kidou Senshi Gundam Cross Dimension 0079" (Video game)
- Key Animation - "Kidou Senshi Gundam PERFECT ONE YEAR WAR" (Video game)
- Key Animation - "Kidou Senshi Gundam" (Video game)
- Key Animation - "Serial Experiments Lain" (Video game)
- Key Animation - "Spiral Zone" (ep 5)!~

node.description:
__Hometown:__ Brooklyn, New York City, New York, USA

Emily Bindiger is an American singer who is part of the a cappella group the Accidentals.

In the anime world she's known for her collaboration with composer and song writer [Yuki Kajiura](https://anilist.co/staff/100077). Bindiger and Kajiura first met during production of ".hack//SIGN" and Kajiura reportedly "fell in love with her voice." Bindiger performed over 10 of the series' insert songs. Kajiura jokingly called Bindiger "her English teacher" at Anime Expo 2003.

Kajiura and and Bindiger teamed up again for the album Fiction featuring songs from Kajiura's past works as well as three original songs. In 2007 Bindiger performed again for Yuki on [El Cazador de la Bruja](https://anilist.co/anime/2030) performing inserts "forest" and "I reach for the sun" and most recently the insert song in [Pandora Hearts](https://anilist.co/anime/5530) "Everytime you Kissed Me."

Besides working with Kajiura Bindiger has also worked with [Youko Kanno](https://anilist.co/staff/95508) in the [Cowboy Bebop](https://anilist.co/anime/1) OST "Adieu" and "Flying Teapot."
